Package com.github.dakusui.jcunit.framework

This is a public API package of JCUnit.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    TestSuite.Typed.ModelingEngine
    An interface that represents a modeling engine.
    TestSuite.Typed.ModelingEngine.Factory
    A factory interface for TestSuite.Typed.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    TestCase
    A class that represents a test case.
    TestSuite
    A class that represents a suite of test cases.
    TestSuite.Builder
    A builder of TestSuite.
    TestSuite.Predicate
    A predicate base class for a Tuple.
    TestSuite.Typed<T>
    A typed version of TestSuite class.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    TestCase.Category
    An enumeration to categorize test cases based on how it is generated.

Package com.github.dakusui.jcunit.framework Description

This is a public API package of JCUnit. If you want to generate a combinatorial test suite using JCUnit's functionality, but don't want to run it under JUnit, you came to a right place. See also TestSuite.Builder.

Following is a diagram that illustrates relationships between entities that you need to know to build a TestSuite object without relying on JCUnit's test runner. 

   +-----------------+                                      +--------------------+
   | List< TestCase >|                                      |Map< String,Object >|
   +-----------------+                                      +--------------------+
            |                                                         |
            A                                                         A
            |                                                         |
   +-----------------+      +---------+       +-----------+        +-----+
   |TestSuite.Builder|- - ->|TestSuite|<>---->|TestCase   |<>----->|Tuple|
   +-----------------+      +---------+ 1   * +-----------+ 1    1 +-----+
           1|                                 |Category  type |
            |                                 +-----------+
            |
            |               +---------------------------+
            +-------------->|TestSuite.Builder.Predicate|
                          * +---------------------------+

And following is a code example to use this API. 

 001: TestSuite testSuite = new TestSuite.Builder()
 002:     .addFactor("factor1", 1, 2, 3)
 003:     .addBooleanFactor("boolean")
 004:     .addByteFactor("byte")
 005:     .addCharFactor("char")
 006:     .addShortFactor("short")
 007:     .addIntFactor("int")
 008:     .addLongFactor("long")
 009:     .addFloatFactor("float")
 010:     .addDoubleFactor("double")
 011:     .addStringFactor("string")
 012:     .addEnumLevels("enum", TestCase.Category.class)
 013:     .addConstraint(new TestSuite.Builder.Predicate("aConstraint") {
 014:         public boolean apply(Tuple in) {
 015:             return !in.get("factor1").equals(1);
 016:     }})
 017:     .enableNegativeTests()
 018: .build();
 019:
 020: for (TestCase each : testSuite) {
 021:     ...
 022:     for (Predicate violatedConstraint : TestSuite.getViolatedConstraints(each) {
 023:         ...
 024:     }
 025: }

Line 002 is defining a new factor with a name factor1 and its levels are 1, 2, and 3. Also you can define a new factor using preset levels for all primitive types and String (Line 003-011). If you use TestSuite.Builder.addEnumLevels(String, Class) method, you can add a factor whose levels are enum constants of the enum. (Line 012).

You probably want to define some constraints over your test suite. For this, you can use TestSuite.Builder.addConstraint(com.github.dakusui.jcunit.framework.TestSuite.Predicate) method. The argument is a predicate which returns false when a given tuple violates a constraint that is represents.

In this example, if a level of a factor factor1 becomes 1, the constraint defined by Line 013-016 will be violated.

By default, test cases that violate any of given constraints will not be contained in the test suite returned by build() (Line 018). But in this example we are explicitly requesting the builder to generate "negative tests" by calling TestSuite.Builder.enableNegativeTests() (Line 017).

If it is requested, after "regular" test cases, "violation" test cases will be appended. Violation test cases are generated in a following manner.

  1. For each of constraints, a test case that violates only it but none of the other constraints will be generated.
  2. For each level of each factor which is not yet covered by any "regular" test cases, a test case which covers it will be generated by changing the factor's value of one of regular test cases to the uncovered level.

In order to know whether a test case in a TestSuite is generated as regular or violation one, you can use TestCase.getCategory() method which returns TestCase.Category.

Note that even if a test case is generated as a violation one, it may not violate any given constraint. Because if a certain level of a factor is not covered by "regular" test cases, which can happen due to very complex constraint definitions and/or a poor covering array generator, TestSuite.Builder tries to cover it by modifying regular test case. And it is possible the test case happens not to violate any constraint.

Therefore, the TestCase.Category returned by TestCase#getCategory() method should be considered it is representing "how" it is generated.

In order to suppress negative test generation, see TestSuite.Builder.disableNegativeTests().

Line 020-025, since a TestSuite is a List of TestCase (see also the diagram), you can simply iterate it using a for statement. Inside this loop, you can execute each test case, format it into a test design document, examine which factors and their levels are covered, etc. To know which constraints are violated by each test case, you can use TestSuite.getViolatedConstraints( com.github.dakusui.jcunit.framework.TestCase) method. (Line 022-024).

See Also:
TestSuite, TestSuite.Builder, TestCase, TestCase.Category, FactorField, Map
